Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is a spectacular adventurous pirate epic with a long list of fun qualities that succeed in appealing to people of all ages.

Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl succeeds in every section of filmmaking that it sets out to succeed in and is unforgettable.
The cinematography succeeds at reaching an epic scale, as does the excellent musical score and the excellent setting.
The visual effects are incredible and the sound editing blends both features together into making it a massively pleasurable experience for the blind and the deaf.
To further hammer down the time of the film's setting and make all the characters a colourful bunch, we witness excellent makeup, hairstyle and costumes which even succeed at strengthening the actors credibility to have a part in such an epic adventure.
And even with taking on many very dark tones and themes of piracy, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl never loses it's comedic charm and is great for a laugh, largely stemming from the rich screenplay and the powerfully talented lead actor.

Johnny Depp's performance is truly astonishing, because he brings a flawless level of sophistication to Captain Jack Sparrow's dialogue and therefore his delivery is rich with charm and finesse. This would definitely be his best performance that I've seen of him so far, as well as his most iconic character thanks to his rugged look and perfect mix of physical and vocal excellence.
In another charming lead, Orlando Bloom plays an interesting blend of pirate and prince characteristics into his role and comes of with charm and talent. He truly is a skilled actor.
Thirdly, the gorgeous and emotionally talented Keira Knightley brings beauty and civility to her role and evolves from an innocent woman to a badass swashbuckler but never loses her grace in the process.

To summarise, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is a massively fun adventure with a little bit of predictability but a lot of adventure and even a few unexpected twists thrown in there. 
Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl restores your faith in the fun of a pirate themed film and Disney's ability to handle a dark concept.

The first Pirates earns its place as one of the great big-budget epics of the early 21st century.  Johnny Depp's Jack Sparrow naturally overshadows everything, and that's a good thing.  Captain Jack is easily one of the most iconic movie franchise characters, up there near Darth Vader.  The plot is quite convoluted, but it should be, because a character like Jack Sparrow is always involved in a complicated series of misadventures.  The CGI of the cursed pirates should also be praised.  They look like the natural evolution of Ray Harryhausen's stop-motion creatures in old adventure movies.  Pirates also features a well-balanced mix of action, adventure, comedy, drama and romance, with a mix of good and villainous characters and a meta wink at the cliches of Hollywood-style good guys and bad guys.

Starring Johnny Depp, Geoffrey Rush, Orlando Bloom, and Keira Knightley, the film opens with Elizabeth having her first encounter with Will Tuner and she also sees a mysterious ship. Now in the present, a man recently promoted to Commodore proposes to Elizabeth. Through a series of events she is not able to answer and then ends up meeting the notorious Captain Jack Sparrow. He is taken captive after a duel with Will Tuner. However, his mutinous former crew raid the city from their ship the Black Pearl. Elizabeth is taken captive and Jack and Will join forces to rescue her, while the Commodore makes his own arrangements. Once again they face the pirates and end up in grave trouble. Jack, Will, and Elizabeth all prove their bravery and cleverness. Ultimately, they are able to take down the immortal pirates and Captain Jack is let go once again. This film was entertaining with good action and enjoyable character. I thoroughly understand how Jack Sparrow has become an icon.

The Curse of the Black Pearl is a movie filled with amazing special effects, laugh-out-loud moments, and great acting, but it's not all good.  Not even Johnny Depp's Academy Award-nominated performance could completely mask some of the script's weaker moments.  There are some parts where you'll be asking yourself "What the heck is going on?" but you won't mind it too much given the sheer immensity of all the other good things that are happening simultaneously.  Geoffrey Rush is also very good here.  Gore Verbinski knows how to direct very well and he's got the motor running on full speed with his beautiful camera work and perfect editing.  It's the script that's mainly the problem, but there's nothing too badly wrong with it.  The movie is fun, exciting, and worth your time.  "Heck yeah."

As I go back and watch Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, I find the viewing experience just as much fun as the first time I saw the film in theaters.  I also find the film more and more ridiculous.

When I first saw the film I was 13 years old, and I was just starting to realize that I wanted to be in the filmmaking business.  Where films like American Beauty, Signs, and the films of Kevin Smith and Mel Brooks, really influenced me in the types of stories I wanted to tell, the original Pirates of the Caribbean really influenced the type of colorful characters I wanted to explore with my stories.  In particular, and I'm sure to no surprise, Johnny Depp's performance as Captain Jack Sparrow dazzled me (for the record, and for no particular reason, the other performance that significantly effected me in my life was Heath Ledger's as The Joker).  I can remember imitating him for a long time, something that caused much frustration for my parents I'm sure.  And also probably contributed to my unpopularity in high school.  But I didn't care, I loved the film and the performance, and it once again helped solidify my certainty in wanting to write movies for a living (now that I think about it, this might have been the aspect that frustrated my parents the most.)

At some points the movie has a complicated plot and can also be quite long.  By listening to the commentary of the film, the director even mentions at one point, that at that particular moment in the film (when Captain Sparrow and Elizabeth are stranded on the beach) the audience has all the information they need to end the story.  Yet the film will continue for another 40 minutes.  The film is flawed, as with ALL films I think.  But with the eclectic characters, the overall plot of pirates and treasure, and the fact that it is just a fun ride, what's there not to love about this film?

When I look back now, I have the same feelings I would image a grown up viewer of films like E.T., Goonies, Star Wars, or Raiders of the Lost Ark might feel.  When you go back and watch the movies from your own childhood you are aware of the dated effects and sometimes unbelievable sequences, but you also are reminded of the magical feelings that you felt upon first viewing those images.  Now, I do not mean to compare E.T., Goonies, Star Wars, or Raiders of the Lost Ark to POTC, but the feelings for me are similar.  Classics are in a way defined by the generation in which they were released.  Huge amounts of people saw E.T., Goonies, Star Wars, and Raiders, and some have now deemed them classics of their time.  And if you don't want to call POTC a classic of a more recent generation that's fine, for the record I'm not particularly calling it that.  But I do think that this movie, whether we like it or not, will be around for a long time.  And well deserved.

The first and only decent entry in the Pirates franchise takes the atmospheric wonder of the ride and wraps it around an entertaining story.  For those of us who were caught up in the intrigue of pirates as kids, this film brings all those hours of role play to vivid life.  Johnny Depp's performance elevates it to a new level, and he is solely responsible for one of the stars on my rating.  Geoffrey Rush has the look of someone born to play a role like this, and brings that mysterious, creepy aspect necessary of any pirate story.  There is also an easy to follow, intriguing plot to be found among all the swashbuckling action, which is something the later films sorely lack.  This is an extremely re-watchable film that never seems to get old.

This is a fantastic movie full action, adventure, humor and a hell of a lot more! The film is 2 hours and 40 minutes long, but that time flies by as you are transported into an awesome world of swashbuckling and sword fights.

Johnny Depp's performance is one of his best ever as the slightly camp Captain Jack Sparrow. Even under his tangle of hair and blackened eyes, he will make you swoon and laugh both at the same time with his tonnes of witty lines and mannerisms. Orlando Bloom plays the love struck son of a pirate, Will Turner and play him he does! This roll highlights the diversity and skill shown by some of the greats. We will definitely see big things from him in years to come. In her second roll in big time flick, Kira Knightley plays kidnapped Govener's daughter, Elizabeth Swan. She is also another young, up and coming star with a bright future ahead of her.

The film may not be the most historically accurate pirate film of all times but all that is forgotten as you enjoy the brilliance of this marvelous movie. Did I also catch a subtle omage to the 1953 swashbuckler 'The Crimson Pirate' when Will and Jack walk underwater in an upturned rowing boat? Sneaky!

The only negative thing I have to say, and believe me I don't want to say it, is that fact we are never told the reason why the curse of the black pearl could only be broken by the blood of William Turner (Senior) and in turn by his son. Despite this plot flaw however, Pirates of the Caribbean is a magical journey that will drop the jaws of parents, children and grandparents alike.

The movie that originated the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise was an enjoyable ride which should please the majority. Maybe a little over-hyped but it cannot be rejected for a night in with the family.

Johnny Depp as Sparrow may have been impressive in the sequels though it's when you first witness his witty portrayal of the outcast pirate that you really are impressed. At times, as I wasn't knowing what to expect, Depp had me in stitches on more than one occasion but an actor of his calibre knows there is a fine line between funny and ridiculous - Depp is the former most definitely.

The plot follows Jack Sparrow (Depp) who agrees to join forces with blacksmith Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) on his quest to rescue his kidnapped sweetheart Elizabeth Swan (Kiera Knightley) from the villainous pirates of the Black Pearl. Their leader Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush) is the main figure on the crew and Jack appears keen to finish him off after previous battles in the past.

Rush - who plays Barbossa - is also particularly witty for a central villain but this is a highlight as it shows Gore Verbinski (the director) wants Pirates of the Caribbean to be a fun adventure which isn't overly serious.

Bloom and Knightley are also well cast; you can see on-screen chemistry between the pair which adds to the feeling that you want them to fall into each others arms. Intertextuality from Romeo and Juliet feels present hear although that's not a bad thing as it slots in with the pirate theme somehow.

The verdict is this film is a delight. It has a strong cast, a decent story and excellent effects. What it lacks though is a certain wow factor or heart, it feels a little too mediocre for four stars.

To celebrate the release of the third sequel to the swash-buckling adventure series, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides, Inner Sanctum will be reviewing the first three movies what have made this movie series one of the most successful movie franchises of today, starting with Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl. The one thing that has put some people off this movie is the fact that this movie is actually based on a theme park ride in Disneyland but for all of those worriers, worry not, as this is actually a great adventure movie. While it's true that the story does feel like it's dragging sometimes, it still manages to keep that adventurous feel to it with added humour and a creepy feel to the pirate ghost story. Admittedly, the story does have its flaws but they can be excused since the story is easy to enjoy and fun to watch. Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl boasts a good cast of actors who had given out decent and less memorable performances. However, there were two actors who easily managed to shine throughout the movie and those two were Johnny Depp as Captain Jack Sparrow and Geoffrey Rush as Captain Barbossa. Johnny Depp manages to give out a zany, comedic and, somehow, dramatic performance as Jack Sparrow and Geoffrey Rush was scary as Captain Barbossa, Jack Sparrow's rival.

The script for Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is good with a few scenes where it intrigued you and the direction for a pirate movie is nearly faultless. The problem with Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is not with it's script or the direction but with the characters. Captain Jack Sparrow is a fantastic character that's full of life and personality, Captain Barbossa makes a brilliant villain with quite a strong personality, actually making you feel quite sorry for him and his crew a couple of times in the movie. However, the problems are two of the three main characters in the movie: Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner, as both of them have a simple personality that isn't relatable in any way and, although Will Turner does have a back story to his childhood, you couldn't really care about it as much as you wanted to. Elizabeth Swann, however, seems to have hardly any personality through the entire movie except for the fact that she's fascinated with pirates, in love with Will Turner and is the Governor's daughter. Fortunately, the movie is very entertaining and a lot of fun for you to notice. Overall, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is a great adventure movie that those of all ages will enjoy.

Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is definitely one of the better pirate movies and one of the better Disney movie series in a way that, even though this is Disney and they are well known for catering to adults as well as children, the pirate ghost story that is the main focus in this movie is more for a mature audience from young teenagers onwards. Younger ones may enjoy this movie but there are some scenes in the movie that could be a little too scary for them. The special effects in Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl are brilliant and nicely used and the action scenes are also done well. Overall, this is one of the best adventure movies and is certainly one of the best pirate movies. From the creepy beginning all the way to the end, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl simply does the job it was supposed to do and takes you on an adventurous journey you'd never want to end.

This movie had almost nothing going for it. A movie, based on a pirate ride at Disney, doesn't sound to promising. But it exceeds almost all summer blockbusters released before, or since.

The story is about a pirate named Jack Sparrow. And about a blacksmith named Will Turner. Will is in love with Elizabeth Swan, and Elizabeth is kidnapped by un-dead pirates. Jack has a history with these un-dead pirates, and their captain, Captain Barbossa (played to the hilt by Geoffrey Rush.) The story unfolds, with Jack and Will trying to save Elizabeth.

Johnny Depp's portrayal of Jack Sparrow...Captain Jack Sparrow has become legendary. And it deserves every bit of praise. Amazing. Orlando Bloom does well with the slightly innocent Will Turner. Kiera Knightley is beautiful and plays a convincing Elizabeth. And the supporting cast of pirates all have fun and Are fun.

Overall this is the pirate movie to end all pirate movies. It's funny, witty, action packed, romantic, swashbuckling, and just a grand time. Also listen for Klaus Badelt's now iconic score. Wonderful stuff. 10/10

PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL is an excellent summer blockbuster and nautical swashbuckler with a modern edge, both in large part due to Gore Verbinski's actively engaging direction and Terry and Elliot Russio's inventive screenplay.  We all know and love PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN, for many reasons: Johnny Depp's irresistibly gonzo Jack Sparrow, the incredible action sequences, the rousing scores by Hans Zimmer, the gorgeous Caribbean locales, and the modern edge the story gives to the traditional setting and characters of 17th Century Port Royal and the surrounding Caribbean islands.  That's why the quadrilogy has now made more than 1 billion dollars and is now among the echelons of franchises that have made as many fans (who continually return to the films via rentals and their collections) as the profit the films have rightfully earned.    

As previously mentioned, Johnny Depp's creatively gonzo and witty rogue of a pirate Jack Sparrow is a real treat to watch every time (whose character traits and personality-type was inspired by a close friend of his, Keith Richards according to a 2006 Rolling Stone article (when DEAD MAN'S CHEST came out).  Keira Knightley's breakout role as the governor's independent and forward-thinking daughter Elizabeth Swann is here, and so is Orlando Bloom is fine Erroll Flynn-esque form (and in 2003, the first time we saw him as someone other than Legolas) as the blacksmith-turned-pirate Will Turner (as we all know, his character and family history play a big part in BLACK PEARL's story).  The rest of the cast does just fine, but what really anchors PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN is its engaging and unexpected story along with entertaining, high-seas action.  
  
Having seen this movie three times (many people have definitely seen it more), this movie improves with each viewing after 9 years.  The sequels were more special effects-heavy and more cluttered with unnecessary story threads, yet the first PIRATES is undoubtedly the best.  Plus with seeing Industrial Light and Magic's pioneering special effects work on the skeleton pirates blew my mind way back when.  

In the most favorable sense, PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL is an enduring, modern-edged nautical swashbuckler and an excellent summer blockbuster packed with fine acting and a unforgettable Johnny Depp performance; incredible high-seas action sequences, a rousing Hans Zimmer score, and an inventive story that brings a modern edge to the traditional settings of British-controlled Port Royal and the surrounding Caribbean.

Pirates of the Caribbean: The curse of the black Pearl (2003) is such a great film. It was directed by Gore Verbinski in the genre of adventure and action. The role of the main character, Captain Jack Sparrow, is played by Johnny Depp. His character is an eccentric and selfish pirate such as Captain Barbossa, who is played by Geoffrey Rush. The cast also includes Orlando Bloom as Will Turner and Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Swann.
When Elizabeth is kidnapped by a group of pirates led by Barbossa and taken aboard their ship, The Black Pearl, Will Turner, the young man who loves Elizabeth sets out to rescue her. But he can't do it alone, so he enlists the help of Jack Sparrow. Together they go after Elizabeth and of the Black Pearl, but they soon discover that the captain and his crew are cursed to remain between the living and the dead, they look like skeletons at the moonlight. Believing in the fact that the curse can be broken by Elizabethâ(TM)s blood they go to Isla de Muerta to put back the last coin, with her blood, of the cursed treasure, back into the chest. However she's not the daughter of Bootstrap, Will is. 
It was only possible with extraordinary special effects and an unforgettable soundtrack. You will always hear about Johnny Depp and his incredible performance and about the day they almost caught Captain Jack Sparrow. This is a very fast - moving and gripping film, it's definitely not predictable and it's over all a memorable plot.
I could watch it many times and never get sick of it. I hope that its sequel be as good as this one. Thatâ(TM)s my tip to you: watch Pirates of the Caribbean, you wonâ(TM)t be disappointed.

The pirate Jack Sparrow (Johnny Depp) and the blacksmith Will Turner (Orlando Bloom) teams up to rescue the kidnapped Elisabeth Swann (Keira Knightley) from the pirates of the Black Pearl, who needs Elisabeth's amulet (which she has taken from Will)and her blood to break the curse, that has made them half dead/ half alive. 

The movie is a very enjoyable popcorn flick. Lots of funny action scenes with brilliant ideas, well done stunts and good special effects.
 Johnny Depp does a great job as captain Jack Sparrow, a pirate with a very weird mime, who is a good person, but not always on the right side of the law. I also like Keira Knightley as Elisabeth Swann, an upper class yet strong woman. Orlando Bloom is pretty average as Will Turner, he isn't a very good actor, but he is tolerable in this one, because his character is very interesting. Geoffrey Rush is great as Barbossa, the captain of the Black Pearl, a brilliant villain.
Most of the minor characters are pretty good as well, but a few of them are a little forgettable.

I like the story, it fits the time and pirate legend pretty good, it is a great adventure. The dialogue is also well written, lots of funny moments. I would have liked a little more character development and a little less action, but I was very entertained.

This movie is way better than the awful sequels, where the characters were used wrong and their motivations were not always clear, also the plot in this one is way better than in the sequels.

8/10

Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl is flawed fun.  It's mostly predictable, it's got some good gags, but it's heavily flawed.

The film has literally HUNDREDS of contradictions and plot holes.  I enjoyed the film, but the contradicitions were distracting.

This film has a fantastic first half hour.  It's funny, and thrilling at times.  However, after that first half hour, the quality drops.  It's still enjoyable, and you will be entertained, but it never lives up to that first half hour.

The musical score is VERY good.  There were too many hands in the score for me to properly credit anyone, but Hanz Zimmer played a big part in the score, and it shows.

The action, is mostly generic, and will never have you on the edge of your seat.  At times, the action is even predictable.  At the minimum, it's passable, and not terrible.

The acting is strong.  Performances from Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, and Geofferey Rush shine.

The story is a little on the cliche side, but it's a silly tale, and no one really cares.

In addition to contradictions, there were a lot of moments where I rolled my eyes at the improbability of it all.  Of course, teenage boys tend to eat that stuff up.

POTC: TCOTBP is a fun, albeit flawed movie, that's probably best for teens and tweens with low expectations.

Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Peal is a spectacular swashbuckling adventure that's tremendously entertaining.  While basing a film on a Disney theme-park ride sounds like an incredibly idiotic idea, the story is actually rather smart and well crafted: a rouge pirate named Captain Jack Sparrow is enlisted to help save the governor's daughter, who's been kidnapped by a ship of the damned that is plundering the Caribbean, looking for a lost piece of treasure that will lift their curse.  The film is well cast and launched the careers of Keira Knightley and Orlando Bloom.  It also propelled Johnny Depp to superstardom, as his inspired performance as the eccentric and charismatic Captain Jack Sparrow turned the character into a pop-culture icon.  The CGI effects work for the most part, and the score's outstanding.  Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is a wildly entertaining and fun high-seas adventure.  Savvy?

Based on a ride at DisneyWorld, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl is not the shipwreck it was thought to be before release.  It's an epic tale of pirates with a unique twist:  The daughter of Governer Swan, Elizabeth Swan, has the last piece of cursed Aztec gold she found on Will Turner when they found him floating through the wreckage of a ship destroyed by the Black Pearl.  I personally loved the way Pirates of the Carribean wasn't a stereotypical pirate film, but was a historical fiction film with a twist of fantasy.  I also liked how Jack Sparrow would seem like one of the worst pirates they had ever encountered, then escapes against the odds.  In conclusion, Pirates of the Caribbean is a fun tale of immortals attempting to become mortal again.

Definitely the best film of the entire series. The writing was very well done and the acting seem to be much better than the other films. When this film was released, Keira Knightley was jailbait age of 18 and Johnny Depp was, well, Johnny Depp. However, this film made Johnny Depp into something he's never been before: a bona fide action star. This was definitely some of his best work and he rewrote the book on how to play the rogue and how to play the hero in family films. POTC: The Curse of the Black Pearl was an epic hit for many fans and I loved hit, the fans loved it which everyone seemed to like. The story starts off With Elizabeth Swann played by Keira Knightley who is kidnapped by a group of pirates led by Captain Barbossa played by Geoffrey Rush while The Black Pearl himself Will Turner played by Orlando Bloom sets out to rescue her but he can't do it alone so he calls Captain Jack Sparrow for help played by Johnny Depp to save the daughter of Governor Swann played by Jonathan Pryce and that's pretty much where all the fun begins. The plot was epic, the story was epic, the acting was epic, the dialogues were epic, the fight scenes were epic, the special effects were epic, the movie was just epic. I give this movie a 10/10.
All three of these movies are great.

Although it is overly long and there are some things in it that are unnecessary and don't make much sense, I have to say "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl" still holds up to this day. It is solidly directed (kudos to Gore Verbinski) and competently made, a lot of the practical effects and visual effects do not feel dated, but more importantly, the film wouldn't have worked without Johnny Depp's Captain Jack Sparrow. He makes this character so charming and likable, and the film wouldn't have been as fun as it was if he had played it straight. The action in the final act is a lot of fun, and Hans Zimmer's iconic theme song totally enhances the experience. I do have some major issues with the film, and one of them being the first 35 minutes. Everything that happens in here have absolutely nothing to do with the main story, and I just thought it could've been a lot shorter. Also, there are some events that make no sense in terms of plot, and I was slightly bored when that was happening. But overall, I have to admit I had a good time watching the film. It is a perfectly enjoyable family entertainment.

The first POTC film is the best one in the franchise, the only film franchise based on a Disneyland attraction that actually got somewhere!  (The two others are The Haunted Mansion and The Country Bears.)  This movie has a great cast doing terrific on their characters, including Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, and Geoffrey Rush!  The guys who play Pintel and Ragetti are also really good!  The film has great special effects, no dirty language...unless you count "bloody" as in "bloody pirates" and "condemn" as bad words, and a fun and very catchy soundtrack!  Jack Sparrow is hilarious, and not many could play the part like Johnny Depp!  I know this is a movie you'll want to watch again and again!  And a quick heads-up for you, their is a post-credits scene.  It's not very important to the movie, but it doesn't hurt the movie at all.

A refreshing and entertaining film, 'Pirates of the Caribbean' is still one of the most overrated movies of its time.
 
Despite being entertaining, the acting (outside of Depp) is all around awful. Bloom and Knightley are both mind-numbingly bad (surprised?) and the script is mediocre at best.
 
The things that make this movie are its fast pacing, great special effects, and Depp's iconic performance. Rush is also good in his role, as is under-appreciated character actor Kevin McNally. So while Pirates is a good action romp, it is not what I would call a great movie.

I think in terms of just pure fun, "The Curse of the Black Pearl" is an adventure movie at its finest. This movie is a complete blast from start to finish. This movie flies well above the rest when compared to the rest of the series. To this day, this is one of Johnny Depp's most iconic performances and I think its easily his best portrayal of Jack Sparrow. I also love the musical score in these movies and think it works in a truly epic fashion in this one. I've spent most of my life watching this movie over and over again, and I think it is one of those movies I can always rely on if I just want to have a fast-paced good time.

The ability to the take the Disney Ride that is Pirates of the Caribbean, and turn it into this movie is phenomenal. Anyone looking for adventure, comedy and action will be pleasantly surprised by this movie, as all 3 are done extremely well. Johnny Depp's interpretation as the shifty, cheating, but charming Captain Jack Sparrow is one of the best original performances I have ever seen. I went into this movie with no expectation and left with it being one of my favorite movies. Although the films does drag at some moments and loses some of its swagger on repeat viewings it is still proof that Disney can make excellent movies.
